Nothing is there to stop them from going further because they hold themselves accountable to no one. Once a law is passed that the voters don't like, it is too late to do anything about it at the next election...Obama's health care bill is a prime example, not only did the majority of the people not want it, most of those voting for it didn't understand it even if they had read it. Message.Msg: ... “Keeping in mind of course that our government seldom stops with the first step.” Oh, for goodness sakes, when will you ever stop with such nonsense.? That’s right, any regulation is bad regulation. What a crock. “…if they could take away one kind of gun, then what is to keep them from logically taking away ALL of them?” Well, let’s see…how about that the new regulation would specifically set what’s allowed and not allowed, and very specifically confirm it has no intention of overturning your 2nd amendment rights. That probably isn’t good enough for you, because you obviously are of the mindset of a government conspiracy against everything you represent. Unfortunately, just because you cry, “but what’s to prevent them from doing this…or doing that”…doesn’t mean a thing to logical people. Murder is often a capital offense…Cancel that…’what’s to prevent them from making shop lifting punishable by execution?” Great logic, Winnie. Have you ever really debated beyond your cubicle? “Nothing is there to stop them from going further because they hold themselves accountable to no one.” Another bizarre statement. Law abiding citizens hold government accountable to the citizenry. Government, IS, in fact, citizens just like you and me. It gets really old having you wacko Tea Party types constantly suggesting that our duly elected government officials are in your opinion, comparable to foreign enemies upon whom you want to wage your fundamentalist war. Grow up and accept that you lost the election. “Gun laws, changes to immigration, etc. are just the next steps…” The next steps to what?…oh, right a Marxist takeover. Trotsky’s outside your home right now stealing your hubcaps. Grab your guns. “Meanwhile, the tax code is still so convoluted no one can really understand it…” Excuse me??? The tax codes presently favor the wealthy and corporations. Yes, people are trying to do something about that which was a prime issue in the last election. Who do you think continues to fight that tooth and nail? (Hint: look in the mirror.) “…the unemployment rate is still higher than ever…” total Bull. ‘…and our economy is still in the tank…” – but slowly recovering from your trickle down scheme, despite your desire to obstruct anything to benefit anyone other than the one-percenters. “Yeah, good government is getting harder and harder to find.” Oh, right, you look for good government. Sure you do. If you Wall Street pimps had your way, ANY government would be hard to find. Your laissez-faire attitude fits your opening statement: “Keeping in mind of course that our government seldom stops with the first step…if we allow any regulation to Wall Street, the next thing you’ll know they’ll want us to tell the truth about insider trading, merger arbitrage, derivatives, and the asymmetrical information which permits us to exploit the situation… then where will we be.?” “Slippery slope, anyone?” It appears to me that you guys have created your own slippery slope, and your downward spiral will continue until you change your tune. Fighting reasonable gun control legislation is a prime example of you being totally out of touch with a majority of Americans.

I would prefer the school not need them, and I would prefer those children not live in communities where they may get shot. This is a failure, Jon. A reversion to the state of nature, a failure of our government and our civilization. People who need AR-15s to go to school or leave the house are not free. They live in fear. Those guns from the Fast and Furious operation were purchased legally by straw buyers, Jon (Agents did not purchase them, they tracked the purchasers). It was illegal to smuggle them into Mexico, but it was not illegal for those gangs and druglords to purchase them in the United States. They did not need to smuggle them back into California from Mexico. If gangs and druglords in the United States want AR-15s, they merely need to go to Walmart and purchase them. According to the BATF, 70% of the guns seized in Mexico from 2007 to 2011 were purchased legally in the US. We are creating and feeding the drug gang violence that make it necessary for schools in southern California to be armed with AR-15s. A situation which you seem very proud of.

Topic.Title: The REAL Killer, List Of School Shootings Known To Be Linked To SSRI's

Message.Msg: That's not logic. It's not even factual. What on earth makes you think there were no drugs in 1927? They put cocaine in Coca-Cola back then for christs' sake. Lithium, Opium, you name it, were widely available and used and abused. But even if your "FACTS" (as jon would put it) are true, and school shootings and drug use increase at the same time, that is no indication that drugs cause school shootings, or that school shootings cause drugs. The famous example of this fallacy is the actual fact that both ice cream sales and crime increase in the summer months. Does that mean that ice cream causes crime? Or crime causes ice cream sales? Nope. It means it's hot out. Whatever drives people to commit mass shootings, banning assault rifles means they will not be able to kill as many people in as short amount of time as they have been able to do since the assault rifle ban was lifted. Now there's a relationship you should look into. But the idea here that we can prevent random violence by properly prescribing anti-depressants is just ludicrous. It is just a lame attempt to obfuscate by the NRA.

Message.Title: T's Report Looks Good
Message.Msg: Besides overall revenue growth, the wireline performance looks encouraging and the 6% share buyback is a nice kicker. That's more than the 5% IBM usually does. Message.Title: Strong Growth in Wireless and U-verse Drives Revenue and Adjusted Earnings Per Share Growth in AT&T's Fourth-Quarter Results
Message.Msg: Strong Growth in Wireless and U-verse Drives Revenue and Adjusted Earnings Per Share Growth in AT&T's Fourth-Quarter Results Full-Year 2012: Strong Earnings, Record Cash Flows, $23 Billion Returned to Shareowners 2013 Outlook: Solid Revenue Gains, EPS Growth in Upper-Single Digits with Continuing Free Cash Flow Strength Dallas, Texas, January 24, 2013 ShareThis $(0.68) diluted EPS in the fourth quarter compared to $(1.12) diluted EPS in the year-ago period. Excluding significant items and adjusting for the sale of Advertising Solutions, EPS was $0.44 versus $0.40, up 10 percent year over year For full-year 2012, excluding significant items and adjusting for the sale of Advertising Solutions, EPS was up 8.5 percent year over year Consolidated revenues of $32.6 billion, up 0.2 percent versus reported results for the year-earlier period, and up 2.8 percent excluding Advertising Solutions and Superstorm Sandy impact Record cash from operations of $39.2 billion and record free cash flow for full-year 2012 $4.4 billion in stock buybacks in the fourth quarter with 126.6 million shares repurchased; for the full year, the company repurchased 371 million shares, or about 6 percent of shares outstanding, for $12.8 billion $23 billion returned to shareowners in 2012 through dividends and share repurchases Record Smartphone Sales and Strong Wireless Postpaid Net Adds Wireless revenues up 5.7 percent versus the year-ago quarter; wireless service revenues up 4.2 percent 780,000 wireless postpaid net adds, largest increase in three years; 1.1 million increase in total net wireless subscribers Record smartphone sales of 10.2 million, the most ever sold by any U.S. carrier; postpaid smartphone customer base now 47.1 million, up 2.5 million from third-quarter 2012 Smartphones 89 percent of postpaid phone sales Postpaid wireless subscriber ARPU (average monthly revenues per subscriber) up 1.9 percent to $64.98 Wireline Consumer Revenue Growth Accelerates Wireline consumer revenue growth continues to accelerate, with revenues up 3.0 percent versus the year-earlier period, their strongest growth in more than four years 36.3 percent growth in U-verse® revenues 8.0 million total U-verse subscribers (TV and high speed Internet) in service; a net gain of 192,000 U-verse TV subscribers and 609,000 high speed Internet subscribers Total wireline broadband data ARPU up more than 10 percent year over year Note: AT&T's fourth-quarter earnings conference call will be broadcast live via the Internet at 4:30 p.m. ET on Thursday, January 24, 2013, attDOTcom/gen/press-room?pid=23672&cdvn=news&newsarticleid=35937&mapcode=corporate|

"Insiders" are ALWAYS selling shares. They are also ALWAYS buying shares. I use DCA with my dividends and over the years ( about 55 years) it has given me a much better return than any other method I've tried. In 11929 T sold for $300. In 1937 it sold for $70. But, it paid the same $9 per share dividend. It eventually went back up to about $150. Had you hung on for 20 years and reinvested those dividends you would have more than covered losses and made an over all decent return.
